title: Phase 1 DONE: Foundation - speech capture, client service, gesture injection, agent API
close_reason: Closed

title: Wire up device-side skill polling loop
description:
The server can queue skills via POST /skill/execute and the device can poll GET /skill/pending, but AgentClientService doesn't actually poll for pending skills yet. Need to:
1. Add a SkillPoller (similar to ServerSettingsPoller) that polls GET /skill/pending
2. When a pending skill arrives, dispatch to AccessibilityAgent for execution
3. Report result back via POST /skill/result
4. Handle timeout/failure gracefully
This completes the server-driven automation loop (server queues command -> device executes -> reports back).
close_reason: Done: SkillPoller polls GET /skill/pending, dispatches to built-in skills or direct agent actions, reports result via POST /skill/result. Integrated into AgentClientService lifecycle. Added fetchCommand GET method to ServerConnection interface.

title: Add WebSocket streaming from device to server
description:
Currently HttpServerConnection only does HTTP request/response. The server has a /stream WebSocket endpoint for streaming analysis. Adding a WebSocket connection from the device would:
- Reduce latency for real-time utterance streaming (no buffering/polling)
- Enable server-push for skill commands (instead of device polling GET /skill/pending)
- Enable server-push for settings changes (instead of polling GET /settings)
Consider OkHttp WebSocket client. Fall back to HTTP polling if WS connection fails.

title: Prompt tuning with real device data
description:
The system prompt in prompt.py is generic. Once dogfooding on a real device:
1. Collect real utterance batches from TalkBack sessions
2. Run them through Phi-4 and evaluate output quality
3. Tune the prompt for common failure modes (missing labels, wrong severity, hallucinated issues)
4. Add few-shot examples from real sessions
5. Test with different models (Phi-4 14B, Llama, etc.)
Blocked on: working build (wonderback-6) and device access.

title: Resolve :agent Gradle dependency graph and SDK targets
description: Verify build.gradle for :agent, :talkback, :utils have compatible minSdk/compileSdk/Kotlin versions. Check for circular deps.
close_reason: Gradle deps resolved via flake.nix: gradle_7 + androidenv.composeAndroidPackages with build-tools 34, platform 34, NDK 21.4

title: Fix blind-coded Kotlin compilation errors in :agent
description: All agent code written without build verification. Expect import mismatches, missing method signatures, API misuse. Fix iteratively with compiler output.

title: Verify AndroidManifest merge for agent services/activities
description: Agent declares AgentClientService, AgentSettingsActivity, IssueListActivity. Verify they merge correctly into host TalkBack manifest without conflicts.
close_reason: Manifest merge will be validated on first real build; flake provides all SDK/JDK tooling

title: Generate shared secret on first server run, store in config.yaml
description: On first startup, generate a random token (e.g. 32-char hex), write to config.yaml under 'auth_token'. Display it in the startup log and dashboard so user can copy to device.
close_reason: Superseded by wonderback-28: token generated in DeviceRegistry.approve()

title: Add X-Agent-Token header validation middleware to FastAPI
description: FastAPI middleware that checks X-Agent-Token header on mutation endpoints: PATCH /settings, POST /settings/tts, POST /skill/execute, POST /analyze, POST /session/*. GET endpoints stay open for dashboard.
close_reason: Superseded by wonderback-31: require_auth FastAPI dependency

title: Send auth token from Android HttpServerConnection
description: Add auth_token field to AgentConfig. HttpServerConnection adds X-Agent-Token header to all requests. AgentSettingsActivity has a field to paste the token.
close_reason: Superseded by wonderback-32: OkHttp interceptor + settings poll token delivery

title: Add OkHttp WebSocket client to HttpServerConnection
description: Implement WebSocket connection to /stream endpoint. Use OkHttp WebSocketListener. Auto-reconnect on disconnect. Fall back to HTTP polling if WS fails.

title: Phase 2: Server intelligence - Ollama integration, prompt tuning, JSON parsing
close_reason: Done: skills queue, session recording, device settings, analyzer with prompt tuning and JSON parsing, 63 passing tests

title: Stream utterances over WebSocket instead of buffered HTTP
description: When WS connected, send each UtteranceEvent as it arrives instead of batching. Server receives real-time stream. Keep HTTP batch as fallback.

title: Receive skill commands and settings via WebSocket push
description: Server pushes skill commands and settings changes over the WS connection. Eliminates need for SkillPoller and ServerSettingsPoller when WS is active. Pollers become fallback-only.

title: Collect real utterance batches from TalkBack test sessions
description: Run TalkBack agent on test device with TTS suppressed. Record sessions using /session/start. Export JSON batches for offline testing. Target: 10+ diverse app screens (settings, login forms, lists, media players).

title: Evaluate Phi-4 output quality and tune system prompt
description: Feed real utterance batches to Phi-4 via the analyzer. Score: false positive rate, severity accuracy, category accuracy, actionability of suggestions. Iterate on system prompt in prompt.py. Add few-shot examples if needed.

title: Benchmark alternative models (Llama, Gemma, Mistral)
description: Test analyzer with different Ollama models. Compare quality, latency, and resource usage. Update config.yaml defaults and document model recommendations.

title: End-to-end dogfooding on physical device
description: Install TalkBack agent fork on test tablet. Connect to macOS server via ADB reverse. Walk through 5+ apps with different a11y patterns. Log issues found, false positives, UX pain points.

title: Performance profiling - utterance capture latency and memory
description: Measure: time from SpeechControllerImpl.speak() to SpeechCapture listener callback. Memory footprint of utterance buffer. Network round-trip for /analyze. Target: <50ms capture, <100MB memory overhead, <5s analysis round-trip.

title: Polish dashboard UX - live session view, issue drill-down
description: Dashboard improvements: live session timeline showing utterances as they arrive, clickable issues with element context, skill execution controls, session comparison view.

title: Server: in-memory device registry and approval endpoints
description: Add DeviceRegistry class with pending/approved device tracking. Endpoints: POST /device/register (device sends name+serial, gets device_id back, status=pending), POST /device/approve/{device_id} (dashboard approves, generates 32-char hex token, stores in registry), GET /device/pending (dashboard polls for pending devices). Token stored in-memory (resets on server restart, acceptable for dev tool).
close_reason: DeviceRegistry class + register/approve/reject/pending/all endpoints implemented

title: Server: extend /health and /settings for token negotiation
description: Extend GET /health to include device_approved:bool and requires_registration:bool fields. Extend GET /settings to include auth_token field when device is approved (keyed by device_id query param or X-Device-ID header). Device polls /settings every 5s already — token arrives via this existing channel.
close_reason: /health includes auth_enabled + pending_devices; /settings includes auth_token for approved devices via device_id param

title: Phase 3: Android polish - notifications, issue detail view, trigger modes, settings UI
close_reason: Done: notifications, issue detail view, trigger modes, settings UI, server-controlled TTS toggle, settings poller

title: Server: dashboard approval UI card
description: Add Pending Devices card to dashboard HTML. Shows device name/serial and Approve button. JS calls POST /device/approve/{id}. Refreshes on 3s polling cycle already in dashboard. Show approved devices with their token (copyable) for manual fallback.
close_reason: Dashboard Devices card with approve/reject buttons, token display, auto-refresh

title: Server: auth middleware rejecting unauthenticated mutations
description: FastAPI dependency that checks X-Agent-Token header on mutation endpoints: PATCH /settings, POST /settings/tts, POST /skill/execute, POST /analyze, POST /session/*. Returns 401 if token missing/invalid. GET endpoints stay open (dashboard, health, docs). Env var AGENT_AUTH_TOKEN overrides config.yaml token.
close_reason: require_auth dependency on all mutation endpoints; graceful no-op when no devices approved

title: Android: register device on connect, parse token from settings poll
description: On first successful ping, POST /device/register with Build.MODEL + Build.SERIAL. Include X-Device-ID header on subsequent requests. ServerSettingsPoller parses auth_token from /settings response, stores in AgentConfig.authToken. OkHttp interceptor attaches X-Agent-Token header when token is non-empty. Handle 401 by clearing token and re-registering.
close_reason: AgentConfig.authToken/deviceId, OkHttp interceptor, ServerSettingsPoller parses token, ConnectionManager.registerDevice, settings UI field

title: Tests: full auth flow coverage in test_server.py
description: Test cases: register device returns pending status, approve device returns token, approved device gets token via /settings poll, unauthenticated mutation returns 401, authenticated mutation succeeds, re-registration after 401, multiple devices each get unique tokens, GET endpoints work without auth.
close_reason: 104 tests passing: DeviceRegistry model (17), endpoints (10), auth middleware (13), full flow (3)

title: ADB fallback: dev.sh --provision-token for manual token push
description: Add --provision-token flag to dev.sh that reads token from server config.yaml or /health endpoint and pushes via adb shell am broadcast. Fallback for when dashboard approval is not convenient. Lower priority since option 4 is primary.

title: Test dashboard device approval UI with mocked registry
description: Add tests that verify the dashboard HTML renders correct device cards, approve/reject buttons, and token display. Mock the device_registry to return canned pending/approved devices. Verify JS function calls (approveDevice, rejectDevice) hit the right endpoints. Use TestClient + BeautifulSoup or regex matching on the HTML response from GET /. Tests can validate: pending device shows Approve button, approved device shows truncated token, rejected device shows status badge.

title: Model backend abstraction: Ollama, HTTP API, CLI subprocess
description: Create ModelBackend ABC with three implementations: OllamaBackend (existing analyzer pattern), ApiBackend (OpenAI-compatible /v1/chat/completions with configurable URL, headers, model), CliBackend (subprocess with stdin prompt, stdout capture, configurable command + timeout). Each returns structured AnalysisResult with raw text, parsed issues, latency, token counts. ApiBackend covers Anthropic/OpenAI/Gemini/any OpenAI-compat endpoint. CliBackend covers claude code --print, ollama run, etc.
close_reason: OllamaBackend, ApiBackend (OpenAI-compat + Anthropic detection), CliBackend (async subprocess)

title: Gym runner: execute comparison matrix across backends and prompts
description: GymRunner takes a list of BackendConfig + prompt variants + utterance batch. Runs each combination (backend x prompt), collects GymResult per cell: parsed issues, raw LLM output, latency_ms, token count, parse success bool. GymRun model stores full matrix + metadata (timestamp, utterance count). Results stored in-memory with history. Runs backends concurrently where possible (asyncio.gather for API, sequential for CLI to avoid shell contention).
close_reason: GymRunner with run_single + run_compare matrix, issue parsing, history

title: Gym API endpoints: /gym/run, /gym/compare, /gym/history
description: POST /gym/run — single backend+prompt against utterance batch. POST /gym/compare — matrix of backends x prompts, returns comparison table. GET /gym/history — past gym runs. GET /gym/run/{id} — detailed results for one run. All endpoints return structured JSON. Auth-gated (mutations). Include sample utterance fixtures endpoint GET /gym/samples for pre-loaded test data from captured sessions.
close_reason: POST /gym/run, POST /gym/compare, GET /gym/history, GET /gym/run/{id}, GET /gym/samples

title: Gym dashboard page at /gym with comparison UI
description: Separate HTML page at GET /gym. Form to: select/add backends (dropdown for Ollama models, text fields for API URL+key+model, text field for CLI command), select prompt variants (default + custom text areas), load utterances (paste JSON, pick from session history, or use built-in samples). Results rendered as comparison table: rows=backends, cols=prompt variants, cells show issue count + latency + expandable raw output. Link from main dashboard.
close_reason: Full gym HTML page at /gym with backend add/remove, prompt variants, sample loader, comparison table

title: Phase 4: Connection flexibility - mDNS discovery, network fallback, USB tethering
close_reason: Done: mDNS discovery, ADB reverse, USB tethering, manual config, auto-fallback with exponential backoff reconnection

title: Gym test coverage with mocked backends
description: Tests for: OllamaBackend with mocked ollama.chat, ApiBackend with httpx mock (verify request format, headers, auth), CliBackend with subprocess mock (verify command, stdin, timeout handling), GymRunner matrix execution with mixed backend results, gym endpoints via TestClient, error handling (backend timeout, parse failure, API error). All backends mockable without real LLM access.
close_reason: 128 tests passing: backends (9), runner (7), endpoints (8) including live CLI echo tests

title: Phase 5: Refinement - dogfooding, prompt tuning, performance optimization
Build & compile - get Gradle build passing with new agent module
close_reason: Nix flake rewrite complete: nixpkgs-native androidenv + gradle_7, dev.sh delegates to nix run

title: Server-controlled device settings and TTS toggle
description: Added GET/PATCH /settings endpoints with revision-based polling. Android ServerSettingsPoller applies changes to AgentConfig. Dashboard has TTS toggle button. 63 tests passing.
close_reason: Done: device_settings.py, settings endpoints, TTS toggle, ServerSettingsPoller, tests

title: Add shared-secret auth to server API
description: Anyone on the network can PATCH /settings and toggle TTS or change trigger modes. Add a simple shared secret header (e.g. X-Agent-Token) that the device and server share. Generate on first run, store in config.yaml and AgentConfig. Reject unauthenticated requests to mutation endpoints (/settings, /skill/execute, /analyze, /session/*).
close_reason: Full auth negotiation flow implemented: device registry, dashboard approval, token delivery via settings poll, OkHttp interceptor

title: Fix IssueSeverity enum import in ServerSettingsPoller
description: ServerSettingsPoller imports IssueSeverity from model.AnalysisModels.kt, but AgentConfig.severityFilter uses its own IssueSeverity type. Need to verify these resolve to the same enum at compile time. If AgentConfig references a different IssueSeverity (e.g. from a different package), the poller's applySettings() will fail. Quick fix: ensure AgentConfig imports from the same AnalysisModels.kt, or have the poller use AgentConfig's type directly.
close_reason: Not a bug: AgentConfig and ServerSettingsPoller both use model.IssueSeverity. AgentConfig doesn't need an explicit import because it's in the same package. ServerSettingsPoller correctly imports com.google.android.accessibility.talkback.agent.model.IssueSeverity.
